@joshourisman never :)

I'll have to look more closely. The only thing I've ever had to leave the stdlib for was multipart-formdata POSTs, for which I've used the 'poster' module, which was great. If I can get that module's functionality along with an easy-to-use replacement for http* in the stdlib, that's a pretty huge win.
@jonesy thanks!  It's currently just a wrapper for the stdlib libraries, making them a lot easier to use.
unfortunately, multipart form isn't supported yet. I'd love to add it though, if an elegant api for it could be thought of
and if it works w/ Python 3, please submit a recipe for potential inclusion in the upcoming 3rd ed. of the Python Cookbook.
I haven't tested it with python3 yet, but i'll let you know as soon as I do

As a stylistic point, what do you think about raising exceptions for non-success status codes? Something like what remoteobjects does: https://github.com/sixapart/remoteobjects/blob/master/remoteobjects/http.py#L178
originally, only the status code would be recorded
and include the response object on the exception class for issue #2 (which is quite correct)
like that
I suppose I could have requests.STRICT bool you could set
i can think of a few ways to make that easier for you
Right now requests.get("http://nosuch.example.org") will raise an urllib2.URLError; requests.get("http://example.org/nosuch") will return a response with status_code=404
@acdha I could have the request evaluate are True or False when evaluated as a boolean (e.g. 'if r: ...)
@acdha httperrors are still handled
yeah, which makes sense to me
If you're dealing directly with the Request object (which I don't recommend yet)
req.send() will return true or false
hmm
Something like that
I just mention this both because I find it cleaner looking and because I've had a couple of annoying errors in testing due to the one place where I forgot to check the status code
like a regular request
when there was a bad http code response
but: https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/closed#issue/2
and if on, it would raise an error
I suppose I could make a strict arg for the request functions
but that wouldn't save you much trouble really since you have to check the code now anyway

the classical argument really

i see - why tabs?
I think they make perfect sense for code indentation. Anyone can set their own tab-width if they fancy 2,3, or 8 space indents
gothca.
but that's a discussion for another topic :)
it is - i was just curious because I rarely see that convention
yeah, it's sanctioned by pep8, against popular belief
(not that i ever use space/backspace to indent/dedent code :P)
pep8 *recommends* spaces for indentation since some people don't understand them, but it's okay with tabs
* understand tabs
*recommends* not requires
(granted all of PEP8 is only a recommendation in the first place)
